items.title: Breaking: Adelaide Festival Corporation apologises to author Randa Abdel-Fattah
items.description: The Adelaide Festival Corporation, which oversees Adelaide Writers' Week, has apologised to Palestinian Australian author Randa Abdel-Fattah and says she will be invited to speak at its next event in 2027.

items.title: Iran shuts airspace as tensions with US escalate

featured_image.name: Iran airspace closed 'until further notice': state media ...

items.description:
Iran issued a NOTAM late on Wednesday night, shutting its airspace to all flights except international flights with special permission, as Western military officials warned that US military intervention could be imminent. The airspace closure, valid for just over two hours, sparked widespread flight diversions and cancellations across the Middle East amid escalating tensions between Washington and Tehran.

FlightRadar24 announced on X that airspace over Iran began emptying rapidly before the notice was officially issued, with the flight-tracking platform noting: "New NOTAM just issued by Iran closing airspace to all flights except international flights to/from Iran with permission."[1]

items.title: Politicising Bondi backfires for Liberals who got what they asked for
items.description: Federal Liberals are discovering the price of having been so brazen in their politicisation of the Bondi terror attack and many appear to have buyers' remorse.

items.title: Trump weighing Iran strike within 24 hours, officials say

featured_image.name: Trump feels obligated to take action on Iran as ...

items.description:
US military intervention in Iran could occur within the next 24 hours, two European officials told Reuters on Wednesday, as President Donald Trump appears poised to authorize strikes amid protests that have killed more than 2,500 people in what French Foreign Minister Jean-Noel Barrot called "the most violent repression in Iran's contemporary history."[1][2]

An Israeli official also told Reuters that Trump appears to have decided to intervene, though the scope and timing remain unclear. A Washington source close to the administration told The Independent that strikes could be imminent. "President Trump is ready to push the button on Iran," the source said. "It will be a surgical removal of the regime."[3][4]

items.title: US announces second phase of Gaza ceasefire plan
items.description: With little fanfare, the White House has announced "phase two" of the Gaza ceasefire has begun — at least, in terms of how it views the situation with the war-ravaged territory.

items.title: Britain temporarily closes Tehran embassy after protest
items.description:
The British government has temporarily closed its embassy in Tehran and shifted operations to remote mode following a protest by pro-regime activists outside the facility on Wednesday, as Western nations continue to respond to Iran's deadly crackdown on anti-government demonstrators.

"We have temporarily closed the British Embassy in Tehran, this will now operate remotely. Foreign Office travel advice has now been updated to reflect this consular change," a UK government spokesperson told Politico.[1][2][3]

items.title: Why apartments with floor-to-ceiling windows are a 'trade-off' in Australia
items.description: Large glazed windows are a popular design flaw in Australian apartments, according to an expert.

items.title: Trump signs tariffs on semiconductors, critical minerals

featured_image.name: President Trump Signs Executive Order Reclassifying Marijuana As Low Risk Drug

items.description:
President Donald Trump signed two executive orders Wednesday aimed at protecting domestic supply chains for semiconductors and critical minerals, invoking Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act of 1962, the national-security clause that allows presidents to impose tariffs on imports deemed threats to U.S. security.

At a White House signing ceremony, Staff Secretary Will Scharf explained that the critical minerals order establishes "a mechanism, a process by which the United States will seek to secure its international supply chain of critical minerals and critical mineral derived products." The moves represent the culmination of investigations launched by the Department of Commerce in April 2025 into whether imports of these strategic materials threaten U.S. national security.[1][2]

items.title: Trump says Iran stopped killing protesters after his threats

featured_image.name: Trump says Iran wants to negotiate as protest crackdown ...

items.description:
President Donald Trump announced Wednesday that he has received assurances Iran has ceased killing protesters, suggesting his warnings of military action may have prompted the regime to back down amid one of the deadliest crackdowns in the country's modern history.

"We've been told that the killing in Iran is stopping — it's stopped," Trump told reporters during an Oval Office bill signing. "There's no plan for executions. I've been told that on good authority."[1][2]

The announcement came just hours before Iran was expected to carry out the execution of Erfan Soltani, a 26-year-old shopkeeper from Fardis, west of Tehran, who was detained on January 8 and sentenced to death without access to a lawyer or trial, according to human rights groups and the U.S. State Department. Trump did not specify who provided the assurances, though Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi had been in contact with Trump's top aide Steve Witkoff over the weekend.[2][3][4]

items.title: Can writers' festivals survive a 'censorship' crisis?
items.description: The shock cancellation of Adelaide Writers' Week has left many concerned about the future of writers' festivals in an increasingly polarised political world.

items.title: US to suspend immigrant visa processing for 75 countries
items.description: The US State Department will suspend processing of immigrant visas for people from 75 countries, including Fiji, Cambodia, Thailand, Somalia and Brazil, from January 21.

items.title: Taiwan officials arrive in Washington for final trade talks

featured_image.name: Trump Team Nears Taiwan Trade Deal With More US Chip Investment

items.description:
Taiwan's Vice Premier Cheng Li-chiun and trade envoy Yang Jen-ni departed for Washington on Wednesday to advance negotiations aimed at reducing U.S. tariffs on Taiwanese exports, according to a person familiar with the matter who spoke to Reuters. The delegation is expected to arrive late Wednesday or early Thursday for meetings with Trump administration officials in the coming days.[1][2][3]

The trip comes after Taiwan's Office of Trade Negotiations announced Tuesday that the two sides had reached a "broad consensus" on trade matters and were scheduling a final wrap-up meeting. If finalized, the agreement could be announced this month, according to The New York Times.[4][5][6][7][8]

items.title: OpenAI signs $10B computing deal with AI chip maker Cerebras

featured_image.name: AI chip company Cerebras raises $1 billion in pre-IPO funding round

items.description: OpenAI has agreed to purchase up to 750 megawatts of computing power over three years from AI chip startup Cerebras Systems in a deal worth more than $10 billion, according to The Wall Street Journal. The partnership marks another step in OpenAI's aggressive campaign to secure computing capacity from multiple chip suppliers as it races to develop increasingly powerful AI systems.[1][2]

items.title: European nations send troops to Greenland as White House talks fail
items.description: The United States and Denmark continue to disagree over the future of Greenland after a meeting at the White House amid ongoing threats from President Donald Trump threatening to seize the semi-autonomous Danish territory for national security reasons.

items.title: UK, France bolster Arctic presence as Trump presses Greenland demands

featured_image.name: Britain is 'stepping up on Arctic security', Yvette Cooper ...

items.description: British Foreign Secretary Yvette Cooper called on NATO on Wednesday to "step up its military and security presence in the Arctic," warning that the region is becoming "a front line of geopolitical competition" as climate change opens new shipping routes and exposes strategic resources. The appeal came as France announced it would open a consulate in Greenland next month, with both European allies taking concrete steps to counter U.S. President Donald Trump's repeated threats to take over the strategic Danish territory.[1][2]

items.title: Ocean climate engineering could threaten global food supply, study warns

featured_image.name: Climate engineering would alter the oceans, reshaping marine ...

items.description:
A major scientific review warns that proposed methods to combat climate change through ocean-based interventions could pose serious risks to marine ecosystems and global food supplies, even as commercial ventures push ahead with deploying these technologies.

The review, published in Reviews of Geophysics, examines eight climate intervention strategies and concludes that while some approaches carry fewer risks than others, none is entirely safe for ocean life. The authors caution that without careful research, these interventions could disrupt the marine food chain that sustains more than a billion people worldwide.

items.title: Denmark, US remain divided on Greenland after White House talks

featured_image.name: Trump live: Danish FM says Denmark, US still ‘differ’ over Greenland

items.description:
A "fundamental disagreement" persists between Denmark and the United States over Greenland's future, Danish Foreign Minister Lars Løkke Rasmussen said Wednesday after talks with Vice President JD Vance and Secretary of State Marco Rubio at the White House. The meeting, which also included Greenland's Foreign Minister Vivian Motzfeldt, came as President Donald Trump doubled down on his insistence that America must control the Arctic territory.

Speaking after roughly an hour of discussions, Løkke Rasmussen told reporters that Trump has made clear his desire for the United States to acquire Greenland. "It is absolutely not necessary for the U.S. to seize Greenland," he said, urging Washington to engage in "respectful cooperation" over the island.[1]

items.title: Group that has courted controversy for years defiant over hate speech laws
items.description: Controversial group Hizb ut-Tahrir says the government "cannot ban" its ideas, despite its members facing the threat of jail under proposed hate speech laws to go before parliament.

items.title: Risking her life, a young Iranian breaks through the blackout with a message for Trump
items.description: From inside Iran, a defiant voice bravely breaks through the internet blackout to detail the horrors she has witnessed and to tell the president of the United States "the people are waiting for America to intervene".

items.title: Ley signals Liberals won't back PM's 'unsalvageable' hate crime, gun control reforms
items.description: A new offence in the government's bill would outlaw the promotion of hatred based on race, colour, ethnicity or nationality, but some Liberal MPs are flagging concerns it will restrict freedom of speech.

items.title: President Trump Announces U.S. Military Airstrike in Venezuela
items.description: President Trump states the U.S. military conducted its first known airstrike inside Venezuela targeting a dock where drugs were allegedly loaded onto boats[1][2][4].

items.title: Trump Meets Netanyahu at Mar-a-Lago for Gaza Ceasefire Phase Two Talks
items.description: President Trump met with Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu to discuss advancing phase two of the Gaza ceasefire, including reconstruction and responses to Iran[1][4].

items.title: Feds Launch Massive Taxpayer Fraud Probe in Minnesota After Viral Video
items.description: Federal agencies including DHS, FBI, and ICE investigate $110 million in suspected fraud at Minnesota child care centers following a viral YouTube video[3].

items.title: Americans Express Widespread Opposition to AI Data Centers
items.description: Public backlash against AI infrastructure data centers grows, with protests and demands for bans influencing Democratic Party strategies for future elections[3].

items.title: Elon Musk's Humanoid Robot Vision: China Poised to Lead Production
items.description: China prioritizes humanoid robots in tech race with U.S., ramping up production while warning of industry bubble and potential bottlenecks[3].

items.title: Trump-Putin Call Amid Ukraine-Russia Tensions Over Peace Plan
items.description: President Trump spoke with Putin amid ongoing Ukraine conflict, with Russia reevaluating peace plan tenets after Ukrainian denials[1].

items.title: Democratic Gubernatorial Candidates in Wisconsin Focus on Inflation and Trump
items.description: Seven Democrats vying for Wisconsin governor blame economic issues on Trump and emphasize affordability ahead of 2026 primary[3].
